reviewText: A superb series and 'finally' the series wind-up is now available which I pre-ordered on February 1 and which should arrive any day now since its DVD release date on February 11, 2011. I recall watching the entire series in the 60's but this time around [** I have 'all' the seasons (divided into two parts per season] with the wind-up Fourth Season, Part II, on the way] I can watch it again without having to suffer through those usual commercial interruptions! In fact and I'll go one better -- when today's TV, especially some of the excellent Fox channel dramas ["The Shield" ; "Sons of Anarchy" ; "House, MD", et al] became 'sooooo' bogged down with chronic commercial interruptions, I actually prefer to wait it out and get the series in DVD format at the end of the year if only to avoid constant and chronic commercial interruptions which in fact have 'increased' over time but remain just as boring! Anyway, this was a great series and I thought David Janssen was perfect for the part of Dr. Richard Kimble not to mention other semi-regulars like Barry Morse as Lt. Girard and others [like Bill Raisch] with a good mix of well known guest stars [various who reappear albeit in different character roles through the years] and the extra 'bonus' that the final fourth year, both Part I and Part II, was filmed in color as opposed to the first three years [each having a Part I and a Part II for the entire year] but which were filmed in black and white.So too, check out the Amazon vendor prices which can be a cost savings if you can live with pre-owned DVD's although I can say that in all the years I've bought items on Amazon and which has been considerable, both new or pre-owned, I've not been disappointed in using Amazon vendors and in those rare times where there was a problem with a pre-owned item, either the Amazon vendor or Amazon itself made good on it.There are even websites dedicated to the original series and you may wish to check them out. I was as happy and well satisfied to get this series as I was previous purchases on such TV classics as "The Untouchables" [Robert Stack, et al], "Have Gun Will Travel" [Richard Boone] and many, 'many' others now available in DVD including the classic of them all and moving from drama to comedy, the one, the only, the original 39 'classic' episodes of ... "The Honeymooners" with our old TV nostalgia friends, Jackie Gleason and Art Carney as Ralph Kramden and Ed Norton. Tell me you don't remember Norton, and in "The Golfer" episode, to wit: "Step up ... plant your feet firmly on the ground ... shoulders straight ... head forward ... [pauses] ... HELLLLOOOOOO BALLLLLLLLL!""The Fugitive" was well done and is well worth a nostalgic re-look or indeed any new viewers to the classic drama show. This too -- it's 'not' in any chronological order so if you, for example, should receive Part two of a given year before Part I arrives, not a problem! Each spisode is, how to put it, plot self-contained and not dependent on anything that came before it. So too, the finale, a two-parter called "The Judgment" was, as I read, one of the most watched 'two-parters' in television history and according to one source, " ... right up there with 'who shot JR' ... " with regard to the viewer ratings audience. Some reported the final two parter in the series as, and I quote, "... a veritable catharsis for loyal viewers to witness Dr. Richard Kimble finally obtain justice for a murder he did not commit ... ." [sic] . Alas, all the principal actors are now gone in real life -- David Janssen [at the age of only 49 from a heart attack] , Barry Morse, Bill Raisch (the one-armed man who had recurring appearances in various episodes). As for the Hollywood remake with Harrison Ford [** and changing various things around like Kimble going from a pediatrician to a general surgeon and Lt. Girard from a fictional 'Stafford, CT' police lieutenant to a Federal Marshal], I liked it! But the origianl series still has my best vote.Doc Tony
summary: A superb series well worthy of the nostalgic second look!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Although much has been bantered about regarding some music clearance issues Paramount Home Entertainment had in re-releasing this classic suspense series, it all comes down to the show itself and the well-written scripts, numerous guest stars and winding story line that culminates with the famous two episode cliff hanger which finally ties all loose ends together.I was a teenager at the time of the season finale, but like most of the country I sat glued to the TV set to see if the one-armed man would finally be captured; if Richard Kimble would clear his name and if Lt. Gerard would stop his obsessive pursuit of the main character.Watching "The Judgement, Part 2" as a 15 year old when it first aired on August 29, 1967, one little irony escaped me.  The writers [in trying to tie up all the loose ends over the four year run of the series] actually created a doughnut hole in the story line.When (in flashback) we see Richard Anderson as Len cowering on the stairs as Helen Kimball is brutally murdered by Fred Johnson, two things are noteworthy:One, Johnson fingerprints are on the lamp, and he makes no attempt to wipe them off before running away.Two, Len's fingerprints are on the banister of the staircase.This now begs the philosophical question "Exactly what kind of police department does Stafford, Indiana possess?"  No one did a thorough crime scene investigation and lift any prints in the house for testing.  They arrested Richard Kimble solely on the basis that his wife was found dead and that they had quarreled earlier that night... purely speculative and circumstantial evidence by any stretch of the imagination.Another thing that jumped out at me from the amusement park climax was that despite their best efforts to shoot close to the buildings, you can still see the Pacific Ocean in the background, which (of course) was a far distance from Stafford, Indiana.  The scenes were shot at Pacific Ocean Park (1958-1967) just prior to its closing.OK, I know this is fiction, but watching the show again 46 years later, these points just jumped out at me.  Don't get me wrong... I'm still a big enough fan of the series to have purchased all four seasons.From the opening, read by the legendary radio and TV actor William Conrad the story commands your attention.  Overall, it's a first class show from start to finish.Yes, we all knew that somehow, during the last fifteen minutes, Richard Kimble would always find a way to stay one step ahead of the authorities... but it was the thrill of the chase, after all.Clean transfers, crisp audio and great thematic music by Pete Rugolo (as well as classic stock production music), unless your are a die-hard fan who was disappointed when some issues of the DVD volumes had music substitutions due to music clearance issues, you won't be disappointed.
summary: Season 4, Volume Two of "The Fugitive"... leading up to "The day the running stopped"...

reviewText: The Fugitive is among my Top 5 TV shows, I can't believe the running will stop. After CBS learned its lesson with earlier seasons messing with the music and driving the fans nuts it appears that the music will remain unchanged and the picture will be crystal clear, as with all CBS DVD releases. Picture quality is something that you can't find any fault with on any CBS DVD release. I'm looking forward to finally completing this series!

reviewText: Stephen King has called it the best TV series ever, then and now.  I can't argue the fact.  Something so compelling about the show.  I first discovered it on A&E in the 1990's, and I haven't stopped watching since.  I don't know how anyone after watching an episode or 2 could stop either, it was positively brilliant.  This final volume as has been said leaves the original, most beautiful music completely intact.  The music also is the best ever for a tv series.  As to this final volume, the Judgement really pays off, thrilling, mysterious and intense!
summary: The best TV series of all time?

reviewText: The final season of The Fugitive is finally out on DVD, completing the "official" studio release. So much has been said about CBS/Paramount's altering of the series' original music score, that I thought I'd take a quick look back at just how much damage(Is that word too harsh?)has actually been done to the overall product.The consences is that the music of season one is completely original, save for a few minor alterations in things like jukebox music, which is of little consequence. Early reports on the second half of season four, indicate that that set of episodes is also, by and large, untouched. These two seasons comprise 50% of the total number of episodes. People who took CBS/Paramount up on their offer to correct the travesty that was the soundtrack of season two, volume one, can now sit back and enjoy roughly 62% of the episodes in their original, unaltered state. Unfortunately, the track record on the remaining year and a half is spotty, at best. Mr. Dahl would have an exact figure on the number of episodes that are original, compared to those that have been hijacked, but if I had to guess, the percentage would be somewhere in the fifty percentile. That comes to some 18% more completely original entries which, when added to the previous 62%, gives us a figure of 80% original.If this were a classroom, that would net you a "B"...Barely.Does it all sound a little generous? Perhaps. But if we were to then factor in the overall picture quality of the 120 episodes, the grade might well be even higher. CBS/Paramount's DVD releases have been criticized on many fronts, but rarely are the attacks leveled against the visuals. Sure, there are the occasional grainy images, along with some accompanying flecks, but they are the exception, rather than the norm.I await the day when a company like Criterion puts out their own release of this absolutely wonderful series. In the meantime, I'm going to enjoy what I have to the max.
summary: Time to Give Out a Grade

reviewText: Tuesday, February 15th, 2011: The day a classic was completed (on DVD). That was the date when CBS/Paramount released "THE FUGITIVE: THE FOURTH AND FINAL SEASON: VOLUME TWO" in a 4-Disc DVD set, which means that all 120 episodes of that 1963-1967 television series are now available to own.In this final batch of 15 color episodes, fugitive Richard Kimble is kept busy, as he continues to elude the law as well as trying to catch up to the one-armed man.The original 1967 music seems to be totally intact and in place for these last fifteen "Fugitive" shows. And that news deserves a big "hooray".Some of my favorite episodes in this collection include "The Ivy Maze", "Concrete Evidence", "The Breaking Of The Habit", and "The One That Got Away".Of course, the top highlight of this DVD set is the famous two-part final episode, "The Judgment". Part 2 of the series finale became the highest-rated and most-watched single television program in the history of the medium when it first aired in the United States on Tuesday, August 29, 1967.In other countries, however, the finale didn't air until September or October. And even in some parts of the USA, the last episode wasn't shown until September 5, 1967. Hence, a different version of William Conrad's closing narration can be found on some prints of "The Judgment Part 2". This DVD set includes the "September 5th" version of Conrad's narration.Part 2 of the finale was seen by an amazing 72% of the viewing audience in the United States, with ABC estimating that 26 million U.S. homes tuned in to watch the last episode. Those figures are still, to this day, some of the highest ratings ever garnered for a television broadcast. The record was not to be broken for another 13 years, when the "Who Shot J.R.?" episode of "Dallas" eclipsed "The Fugitive's" record in 1980. And then the final episode of "M*A*S*H" surpassed "Dallas" in 1983.In "The Judgment", Richard Kimble teams up with Police Lieutenant Philip Gerard to try and capture the real killer of Kimble's wife. Although very dubious about the results, Gerard agrees to delay Kimble's official arrest for 24 hours, so that Dr. Kimble can follow up some leads regarding the whereabouts of the elusive "one-armed man" (played by the hardened-looking Bill Raisch), whom Kimble is certain murdered his wife several years earlier.While I feel this "teaming" of these two long-time adversaries weakened the last show of the series to a degree, "The Judgment" is still a pretty good concluding episode.The final scene with Kimble and Gerard shaking hands after Kimble's release from custody is truly a great moment in television history. And this scene is carried out without a word of dialogue being spoken, which provides even a more powerful impact -- rather than having a gushy, overly sentimental final act. The simple, understated handshake said it all."The Judgment" features a large guest cast, including Jacqueline Scott, Diane Brewster, Richard Anderson, Michael Constantine, Diane Baker, J.D. Cannon, Louise Latham, and Joseph Campanella. Plus, of course, Barry Morse and Bill Raisch in their recurring parts as Lt. Gerard and the one-armed man ("Fred Johnson").Jacqueline Scott plays Richard Kimble's sister, Donna. Scott had a recurring role as Donna throughout the four years of the series, appearing in a total of five episodes. She did an excellent job in the role, too.Diane Brewster appears uncredited in the final episode, as murder victim Helen Kimble, via flashback sequences. You might better remember Brewster in another classic television series, "Leave It To Beaver", as Beaver Cleaver's schoolteacher.Some "Judgment" facts & trivia:According to "Daily Variety", Part 1 of "The Judgment" received a 37.2 rating and a 56.7 share of the U.S. television market in the USA, while Part 2 garnered a 50.7 rating and a 73.2 share.*------------The final two-parter takes place in three different cities -- Tucson, Los Angeles, and Kimble's hometown of Stafford, Indiana. Kimble's last alias he will ever need is that of "Frank Davis". "The Judgment" was co-written by George Eckstein and Michael Zagor, with both parts being directed by Don Medford.------------The following memo written by Executive Producer Quinn Martin appeared on the last page of "The Judgment's" teleplay:To all QM staff, crew, actors, all guest actors, all ABC personnel, all advertising personnel:This script marks the end of a very exciting and successful enterprise, and I would appreciate it if everyone would keep the contents a secret, and not discuss it with any members of the press or newscasters, except to acknowledge that it does prove Richard Kimble innocent.To any members of the press or any newscasters:If the above does not work, and by chance you find out the contents of the script, please honor the industry code of not giving the ending away, except to say Richard Kimble will be proved innocent. Thank you.Warmest regards,Quinn Martin *------------"In the final scene of the series...the original plan was to have the two adversaries [Dr. Kimble and Lt. Gerard] exchange a few parting words before going their separate ways. "In the first version of that final episode, our writers had gone a little overboard," recalled Barry Morse. "They wrote a scene...in which David [Janssen] and I said sentimental things to each other. At one point, I remember I suggested to David that, in order to mock this overly sentimental dialogue, we should throw ourselves into each other's arms and kiss each other firmly on the mouth! Well, we threatened that, but we never had to carry it out. By that time, we were all on such good terms with each other that everybody realized the absurdity, and it was agreed that we would make some changes in the dialogue. And I think somebody said, 'Well, what would be the best thing to say?' And I said, 'I think it would be best if we say nothing!' As is often...the case on the screen, what you do and what you look is much more eloquent than what you say.""** = Source: Ed Robertson's 1993 book"The Fugitive Recaptured", pages 178-180.====================THE EPISODES:Disc 1:The Other Side Of The CoinThe One That Got AwayConcrete EvidenceThe Breaking Of The HabitDisc 2:There Goes The Ball GameThe Ivy MazeGoodbye My LovePassage To HelenaDisc 3:The Savage StreetDeath Of A Very Small KillerDossier On A DiplomatThe Walls Of NightDisc 4:The Shattered SilenceThe Judgment, Part 1The Judgment, Part 2====================DVD INFO:>> Video is Full-Frame (1.33:1), and in color, as originally aired in 1967. The image quality is quite good. The colors look proper and natural. And there's every reason to believe that these episodes are presented complete and uncut here (time-wise), with the shows running for 51+ minutes each. The "in color" bumpers and opening teasers are included.>> Audio is 2.0 Dolby Digital Mono. Sounds good too.>> Bonus Feature -- There is one bonus featurette (on Disc 4), entitled "Composer Dominic Frontiere: The Color Of Music". Frontiere talks briefly about his career as a music composer.This bonus program, which is presented in an anamorphic widescreen format, runs for 11-and-a-half minutes and is a continuation of a conversation with Mr. Frontiere that began with the "Season Of Change" featurette that is included in the fourth season's first DVD volume.The last 3+ minutes of this bonus supplement include scenes from the final "Fugitive" episode, highlighting Frontiere's music from that show.>> Menus are static and silent.>> A "Play All" button is included on each disc.>> English subtitles are included.>> Chapter stops -- 7 per episode.>> Packaging -- Amaray type of keep case, with two swinging "pages" that each holds two DVDs. Episode information is visible through the plastic on the left and right panels of the case. [Side Note -- There's a glaring error in the description for Part 2 of "The Judgment", with the description saying that Gerard and Kimble are headed for "Illinois". Of course, that should say "Indiana" instead. Somebody at CBS/Paramount should have checked out their facts a little better before writing up that episode blurb.]====================ADDITIONAL "FUGITIVE" MISCELLANY:A BRIEF BIOGRAPHY OF DAVID JANSSEN ("DR. RICHARD KIMBLE"):Born David Harold Meyer on March 27, 1931, in Naponee, Nebraska. He died of a heart attack at the age of only 48, on February 13, 1980.Janssen was nominated for an Emmy Award three times (out of four years) for his work on "The Fugitive".David's roster of acting appearances totalled a little more than 100 television and movie roles, beginning (as a 14-year-old boy) in the 1945 film"It's A Pleasure". Janssen's other big TV role, after "The Fugitive", was when he played private detective Harry Orwell in the series "Harry O" (1974-1976).---------A BRIEF BIOGRAPHY OF BARRY MORSE ("LT. PHILIP GERARD"):Born Herbert Morse on June 10, 1918, in London, England. Died at the age of 89 on February 2, 2008.Barry moved to Canada in the 1950s, where he has worked extensively in live theater, radio, and CBC television.Morse made appearances in more than 130 motion pictures and television programs, starting with a 1942 appearance in the film"The Goose Steps Out".Many people probably remember Morse best from his role as Professor Victor Bergman in the TV series "Space: 1999", which was on the air from 1975 to 1977.Morse also was a writer and director within the TV industry, including one episode as director of "The Fugitive" in 1967 during the last season of the series. Morse directed Episode #118, "The Shattered Silence".In addition to his memorable portayal of Lt. Philip Gerard in "The Fugitive", the long list of TV shows in which Barry Morse appeared includes these programs: "The Untouchables", "The Defenders", "Judd, For The Defense", "The F.B.I.", "Wagon Train", "The Outer Limits", "Naked City", "The Alfred Hitchcock Hour", "The Twilight Zone", and "The United States Steel Hour".====================THAT'S A WRAP:It took 44 years, but all 120 episodes of the never-to-be-forgotten television masterpiece "The Fugitive" have now been made available on the home video market on DVD by CBS/Paramount.And despite the unpleasant debacle with the background music that fans of this series had to endure beginning in 2008 (which, to Paramount's credit, was corrected--for the most part--in subsequent DVD releases), these 120 TV episodes are programs that deserve to be on the shelf of everyone who enjoys really good television shows.In its four seasons on the air, "The Fugitive" created a compelling and realistic "running man" atmosphere that I don't think has ever been duplicated on either television or the big screen since Dr. Kimble stopped running in 1967.And the main spark that created that atmosphere, of course, was the star of the series--David Janssen. And when you throw in the great Barry Morse as the running man's tireless pursuer--how can you lose?120 episodes on DVD, and 0 to go.That last sentence is nice to see, isn't it?I think so, too.David Von PeinFebruary 2011
summary: ONE FINAL VOLUME OF KIMBLE, GERARD, AND THE ONE-ARMED MAN (SEVERAL OF THESE EPISODES ARE BETTER THAN I REMEMBERED, TOO)

reviewText: WHEN I SAW THE FUGITIVE BACK IN THE 60'S I ALWAYS WISHED THERE WOULD BE A WAY TO SEE IT AGAIN AND AGAIN.  I AM SO HAPPY TO OWN THIS COLLECTION.  SORRY I DID NOT GET THE SEASON II CORRECTION THAT CBS OFFERED.  I CAN'T WAIT TO HAVE SEASON 4 VOLUME II.  THE ENDING IS SUPERB AND FOR THOSE OF YOU WHO HAVE NOT SEEN IT YOU WILL LOVE IT!!! NO ONE ELSE COULD HAVE PLAYED THIS ROLE AS GOOD AS DAVID JANSSEN.  WHAT A GUY.  RIP DAVID. INTERESTING THAT IT IS BEING RELEASED RIGHT AROUND THE TIME OF THE 31ST ANNIVERSARY OF HIS DEATH.

reviewText: Season four volume 1 was very nicely done.The color was magnificent sharp and clear.The music of Dominic Frontiere didn't seem to be messed with.What a wonderful addition to anyone's dvd library the complete series now.The Final two episodes is rewarding enough to merit putting time into digesting this series in its entirety.One of the few shows that's has a final episode where the main character lives happily ever after. David Janssen is a joy to watch this talented actor is the reason the series has reached cult status today. God bless ya David we miss ya.IT JUST GOES TO SHOW YOU BOYCOTTING THE SHOW BECAUSE THE MUSIC WAS NOT ORIGINAL DID NOT HURT THE SALES OR FURTHER DVD'S COMING OUT. SORRY THE SHOWS MUSIC WAS NOT ORIGINAL BUT ITS NICE TO HAVE THE PICTURE REMASTERED AND SEE THESE EPISODES FOR THEIR FIRST TIME UNEDITED AND COMMERCIAL FREE.AND THIS COMPLETES MY DVD LIBRARY OF THE FUGITIVE.LOOKS THE THE COMPANY IS NOT GOING THROUGH THE TROUBLE OF PUTTING IN THE ORIGINAL MUSIC CUES THIS IS IT FOLKS I DOUBT ANY OTHER COMPANY WILL PUT THIS SERIES OUT WITH THE ORIGINAL MUSIC OF THE FIRST THREE SEASON.ALL THOSE IDIOTS WHO COMPLAINED ABOUT IT DID NOT CHANGE A THING.OUT OF 8 VOLUMES ONLY ONE WAS REISSUED SO ONE OUT OF EIGHT IS ALL YOU GOT THE REST YOU HAVE TOO TAKE AS IT IS, AND THAT'S THE WAY IT IS LIKE IT OR NOT. MY COLLECTION IS NOW COMPLETE.AT LEAST THOSE IDIOTS WHO TAKE THE MUSIC TOO SERIOUSLY GOT ONE OUT OF 8 VOLUMES CHANGED BUT THAT'S ALL THE COMPANY DID NOT CARE ABOUT THE OTHER SEASONS NOT DONE RIGHT.THE COLOR SEASON WAS DONE RIGHT WITH THE OUTER LIMITS MUSIC BY DOMINIC FRONTIERE INTACT.I DON'T CARE WHAT THOSE IDIOTS HAVE TO SAY ABOUT IT.I don't care what any of you have to say about it the series is done and that's that.THE SERIES IS DONE AND THATS THAT
summary: Yeah baby its time for the finale

reviewText: As was with Season 4 Volume 1, there are no music replacements.  If anyone is considering purchasing this series, stick with Season 1 Volumes 1 & 2 and Season 4 Volumes 1 & 2.  Don't waste your money on Seasons 2 and 3 unless you want to be disappointed.  CBS has badly butchered them.  Furthermore, let it be known that if CBS ever decides to release the original film transfers of The Fugitive to Blu-Ray, they had better release ALL the original musical scores that were used, when the series originally aired on television, in the 1960's.  Otherwise, they need not bother to release anything.  I read all reviews before purchasing DVD's and will not waste any more money on altered tv shows - period!

reviewText: As a matter of fact, I just placed an order for this final installment of the Fugitive series which come to a successive conclusion. I had watched the entire series way back in the 1960's. Now not only have I been able to watch  the series once again but keep all the episodes for future viewing. I wish to thank the producers and Amazon.com for bringing the Fugitive series  for discriminating viewers all over the world. By the same token, let's  hope that the producers which owns THE HIGH CHAPPARAL series will also feel duty-bound and oblige the viewers here to introduce this popular and best Western TV series to the North American public. After all, a German version (duped in English and German) has been available in Europe for sale...so why not a North American version in the coming year of 2011...!?Here's wishing all viewers a Happy Christmas and Happy New Year and please  keep your finger crossed for the possible appearance of The High Chapparal series  soon!  Cheers...!
summary: The Fugitive (final installment) at long last....!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I have long awaited the release of The Fugitive on DVD. I was born in the 1970's and only got my first taste of The Fugitive in the 90's by accident on A&E.; One episode and I was hooked. The Fugitive became my favorite TV show of all time and remains so to this day.The shows' creator and producers and directors were geniuses to match the wonderful talents of David Janssen, Barry Morse, and Bill Raisch together to play the characters that made this show a success. Each actor gives you the feeling that they really are the character that they are portraying in this series.  IMO this season comprised some of the best of The Fugitive story line. You see more of the One Arm Man and have a guest return and reprise their role from a season one episode in "The Breaking of the Habit". Of course we can't forget the booming voice of the narrator, William Conrad. His narrations on each and every episode gave The Fugitive an extra special quality. An extra zing to the show that made it complete.This seasons release mirrors the first season release from CBS/Paramount in regards to the music. All of the back ground music is present from what I have seen.  I don't know if all of the juke box and radio music is the same but I know in the episode "A Clean and Quiet Town" the juke box music is the same and was not changed nor did I pick up on any music change in "The Judgment Part 1 and 2". The only thing I hate about this release is they used the alternate ending date at end of the Epilogs closing narration.  Thankfully in the upcoming box set release, CBS/Paramount has included both versions of the closing narration and, from what I have read so far, have restored pretty much all of the original cues to the season 2 and 3 DVDs that were removed.The DVD's come cased in hard plastic cases as the previous season sets have been packaged. As in my previous reviews, I have to comment on the cover art. I hate it! I have never seen this picture of Janssen before but it is terrible. CBS/Paramount surely has better pictures in their Fugitive archives to have chosen from.  Why they picked this one is beyond me.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I can remember back in 1967 when I had finished work and got home just in time to see the last episode of THE FUGITIVE. At last I would find out If Kimble would really stop runnig. At that  time there was nothing like the phenonimen of THE FUGITIVE on T.V. This release is excellent in it's presentation of that famous episode that was viewed by millions of people. All 13 episodes leading up to the finale are here, in color with the original music score. A pure pleasure is revived again viewing these programs. Amazon, you brought me back in time.John Walsh
summary: Brings me back to what television used to be

reviewText: It's been a long road for this great series on DVD and in some cases, it didn't have to be, except for the stubborn few who found it necessary to quibble over a few bars of music, granted, they wanted to preserve this series in totality and to that end, I salute them but that being said, we must think outside that box and look inward towards the work that the late David Janssen did to make this series was it was, MAGNIFICENT!Within the final 15 Episodes of this set are some of the finest episodes of the series, all in brilliant color and remastered to perfection.SOME GREAT EPISODES:THE ONE THAT GOT AWAY: A Detective (Charles Bronson) boards a boat to catch an embezzler and finds out Kimble is on board.CONCRETE EVIDENCE: A Building Contractor (Jack Ward) Blackmails Kimble to help clear his name for the accidental deaths of 3 children in a building collapse.THE BREAKING OF THE HABIT: Kimble is re-united with Sister Veronica from the first season to aid him in finding the one-armed man.THE IVY MAZE: Kimble gets help from an old College friend (William Windom) who is a college professor specializing in dream studies who has tricked the one armed man who is a janitor there into participating and getting him to confess the murder. (ONE OF THE BEST)DOSSIER ON A DIPLOMAT: Kimble is in Washington DC to meet with a lawyer and ends up tending to a sick African diplomat at the African Embassy, trouble ensues when the diplomat's wife recognizes Kimble and calls the authorities.THE JUDGMENT (PART 1): This is the episode that, at the time, broke all nielson records for the most watched show in Television history.Kimble, while working for a trucking outfit in AZ, spots a newspaper article that the one armed man has been arrested in LA, he quits and gets a ride from one of the trucks into LA,could this be his big chance to finally clear his name?Not likely, the article was posted erroneously by a newspaper but Gerard, notified ahead of time that Johnson has been arrested, flies out to LA and agrees that it's a good idea to let the article stand as is so that he could capture Kimble again.THE JUDGMENT (PART 2): Kimble, after being arrested by Gerard at the end of Part 1, is on his way back to Indiana but so is Fred Johnson who has set up a blackmail scheme with the man who he thinks is Kimble's brother-in-law, Len Taft but is actually LLoyd Chandler, a very important man in the town council in the town of Stafford.LLoyd Chandler has a secret he's been hiding for the past 4 years and it's been eating him up inside and this secret is about to break the Kimble case wide open.SO............Just in case anyone has been on a deserted island and never saw this episode, I won't ruin it for anyone.I have a couple of issues with this DVD though:1. a minor issue....if you look at the synopsis of the episodes, you will see misspellingsin the first episode, they spelled Kimble's name KIMBALL and in THE JUDGMENT, they said thatKimble was on his way back to Illinois, not Indiana....Betcha whoever typed these out, did it on a Friday afternoon or a Monday morning...LOL.2. My second issue is a bit more of an annoyance, I was really hoping for some good bonus material in this last volume, a retrospective on David Janssen would've been nice, some interviews, a look back on his life perhaps but all we get is an interview with the guy who did the music in the last volume.  I just feel cheated we didn't get more Bonus Material in this last Volume, Oh well.Rest In Peace David, Your running has stopped, you're home.
summary: It's a bittersweet ending to a GREAT series!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've read some reviews that complain about the quality of the transfers along with occasional changes in the music cues.  Frankly I think they are being too picky. The show is nearing 50 years old.  The idea of selling it for home use wasn't even a dream back then.  QM Productions was probably thinking of a few years in sydication at best.  It's amazing they look and sound as good as they do. Except for some occasional rough spots they look and sound excellent.Clearance rights for the music can be extremely difficult for old shows. If the producers have to use different music cues than the original ones it's because they couldn't get the rights.  No rights would equal no release, so a reasonable compromise had to be made.  Frankly I have a tough time remembering music cues from nearly 50 old tv shows.  I loved the way the show ended with a handshake and a couple of "Heys!"  Plus he got Diane Baker in the end.  How can you top that!
